Title: City of Chicago v. Equte LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, corporate defendants' principal could not be held personally liable, through piercing of corporate veil, for any fines assessed against them in connection with their online sales of electronic cigarettes and other tobacco-related products in alleged violation of Illinois city's municipal code; neither injustice nor fundamental unfairness would occur if corporate veil were left intact, as there were no allegations that corporate defendants ever owed anything to city, that principal acted willfully to deprive city of something of value, or that principal intended or personally directed the code violations, case instead involved city's attempt to assess fines against principal for corporations' violations of ordinance, and it was not unjust or fundamentally unfair to not pierce the corporate veil simply because city was unlikely to recover any fines that might be assessed against corporations without attacking principal's assets.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporations' principal could not be held personally liable for online e-cigarette sales that allegedly violated municipal code.

Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: When determining whether a common enterprise exists for purposes of liability under Federal Trade Commission Act (FTCA), the court considers the following factors: (1) common control; (2) the sharing of office space and officers and employees; (3) whether business is transacted through a maze of interrelated companies; (4) the commingling of corporate funds and failure to maintain separation of companies; (5) unified advertising; and (6) evidence that reveals no real distinction exists between the corporate defendants. 12 U.S.C.A. § 5538(a)(1).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. Attorneys and mortgage assistance relief providers did not engage in unfair or deceptive practices violative of New Mexico Unfair Practices Act.

Title: In re Lee
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: So-called "exclusivity" provision of Indiana's Dissenters' Rights Statute, under which a minority shareholder entitled to dissent and to obtain payment for his shares is barred from challenging corporate action that created his entitlement, did not prevent minority shareholder which, after dissenting from corporate merger, had obtained money judgment for value of its shares from seeking to pierce veil of corporate entity that was liable on judgment entered under the Indiana Dissenter's Rights Statute, after that entity was stripped of assets following merger, in order to hold its majority shareholder personally liable; in pursuing veil-piercing claim, minority shareholder was not challenging merger that created its right to judgment under Indiana statute, but seeking to effectuate its statutory rights. Ind. Code Ann. § 23-1-44-8(c).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold debtor personally liable.

Title: In re Lee

Title: Clientron Corp. v. Devon IT, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil of insolvent Pennsylvania corporate buyer of Taiwanese computer component manufacturer could not be pierced as a federal discovery sanction to reach husband who was one shareholder but not wife who was the other shareholder, to hold husband personally liable for only part of the judgment against buyer, which husband and wife owned as tenants by the entirety, in manufacturer's action alleging breach of contract and also seeking to enforce an arbitration award; any conclusion that buyer was the alter ego of one shareholder tenant by the entirety, but not the other, was legally untenable under Pennsylvania law, and a new, judicially-created legal remedy could not be inserted into the lawsuit as the means of imposing a sanction. Title: Meinert Plumbing v. Warner Industries, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: Dealers that contracted with flooring business to provide installation services, as part of at-home service program of home improvement chain, were not entitled to pierce the corporate veil of corporation that also participated in the chain's program as independent contractor, in order to hold related parent corporations liable for alleged breach of contract and violation of Business Opportunity Plans Act (BOPA), although the independent contractor corporation allegedly served as agent of other two corporations, and the corporations shared officers and board members and office space; mere agency relationship was insufficient to pierce the corporate veil without a showing of fraud or illegal activity, independent contractor corporation was a separate company with its own assets, payroll, and employees, and evidence did not establish control over the independent contractor corporation by the parent corporations. Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.

Title: Glock v. Glock
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: In support of her claim under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO), ex-wife was not entitled to pierce corporate veil to ignore corporate form and reach assets of Austrian parent corporation, which she owned with ex-husband, as well as subsidiary corporations and related private foundation; while ex-wife claimed these assets belonged to a "partnership" with ex-husband, there was no indication ex-wife and ex-husband had formed a legal partnership, so her claim was no more than a request for division of assets allegedly belonging to former marital estate, which had already been divided in divorce proceeding in Austria, and under international abstention doctrine, District Court could not rule on any claims related to divorce proceedings. 18 U.S.C.A. § 1961 et seq.

Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Individual Chapter 11 debtors' alleged use of corporation as vehicle to evade statutory obligation to make quarterly estimated income tax payments on commissions that would otherwise have been paid to them personally, as opposed to being directed to them through corporate account, did not provide basis for corporate creditor to pierce corporate veil and to hold individuals liable on unrelated claims that it had against corporation, so that bankruptcy court did not have to make any factual findings with respect to income tax issue as irrelevant to whether corporate creditor was entitled to pierce corporate veil and to assert claim in debtors' individual Chapter 11 case. Fed.Rules Bankr.Proc.Rule 7052, 11 U.S.C.A.; Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 52(a), 28 U.S.C.A.

Title: Nicholson v. Allied Interstate, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Although corporate parents cannot be held liable as debt collectors under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA) based upon parenthood alone, a corporate parent is nevertheless liable for its subsidiary's FDCPA violations when the subsidiary is so dominated by the parent company that it is merely an instrumentality of the parent. Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, § 807, 15 U.S.C.A. § 1692e.

Title: Zarichny v. Complete Payment Recovery Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.

Title: U.S. v. Cochran
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Eastern Division.
Headnote: United States failed to plead that individual and corporate landlords and the manager of their residential rental properties were jointly and severally liable for manager's alleged violations of the Fair Housing Act (FHA), based upon a theory of alter ego or piercing the corporate veil, as required for such a theory to be actionable at trial; government's complaint and summary judgment briefing asserted theory of vicarious liability alleging manager acted as agent on behalf of each of the landlords who rented their properties through him, only at eve of trial did government allege that manager acted as agent of all the landlords without differentiation, as a single, integrated enterprise, and that manager and individual landlord used the corporate landlords as alter egos, and piercing the corporate veil was an unusual, exceptional, and specialized theory of relief. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 8(a), 28 U.S.C.A.; Fair Housing Act, § 801 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 3601 et seq.
Document Preview: CIVIL RIGHTS - Pleading. United States failed to properly plead alter ego or piercing the corporate veil theory of liability under the FHA, and thus the theory was not actionable.

Title: Hyland v. HomeServices of America, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: There was no evidence that real estate firm so dominated subsidiary's finances, business practices, and policies as to justify piercing the corporate veil in action brought by home sellers alleging that real estate firms violated the Sherman Act by participating in a horizontal conspiracy to fix the commissions charged in Kentucky real estate transactions at an anti-competitive rate. Sherman Act, § 1 et seq., 15 U.S.C.A. § 1 et seq.

Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.

West's Ann.Cal.Civ.Code § 1750; West's Ann.Cal.Bus. & Prof.Code §§ 17200, 17500.

Title: Eastern Comfort Assisted Living (ECAL) IV and V v. Department of Public Welfare
Court: Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil in order to reach president of corporation that owned unlicensed personal care home so as to order president to cease home's operations and to impose fine was justified; president was sole shareholder in corporation that owned unlicensed home, president was sole shareholder in corporation that operated licensed personal care home that transferred residents to unlicensed home, president directed transfer of residents from licensed home to unlicensed home, and president was fully aware of circumstances surrounding transfer and operations of corporate entities involved. 55 Pa.Code § 2600.262(g); 62 P.S. § 1086(e).

Title: F.T.C. v. Tax Club, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Federal Trade Commission (FTC), State of Florida, and State of New York stated a claim for common enterprise liability among 12 corporate defendants that operated businesses that sold products and services to people seeking to build their own small businesses, which, together with four individual defendants, allegedly engaged in deceptive telemarketing tactics that violated the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTCA) and state law; all 12 corporate defendants allegedly shared the same office space, employed the same telemarketing, customer service, billing, and administrative staff, maintained a highly integrated set of banking services, shared common ownership, and some combination of individual defendants allegedly occupied officer positions at each of the corporate defendants. Federal Trade Commission Act, § 5(a), 15 U.S.C.A. § 45(a).

Title: National Gear & Piston, Inc. v. Cummins Power Systems, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, alleged violations of federal and New York antitrust law were insufficient to serve as a wrong or injustice required to pierce the corporate veil in authorized engine part dealer's action against engine part distributor and manufacturer; the violations were insufficient since they formed the basis of one of the dealer's underlying claims, and there was no indication that the manufacturer was involved in the distributor's alleged scheme or that it committed an antitrust violation through abuse of the corporate form. Sherman Act, § 1, 15 U.S.C.A. § 1; N.Y.McKinney's General Business Law § 340(1).

Title: Gustavson v. Wrigley Sales Company
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: Parent-subsidiary relationship between two producers of food products, standing alone, provided insufficient basis for piercing corporate veil and holding parent liable for subsidiary's conduct in consumer's putative class claims against producers, alleging that package labeling was "misbranded" under California's Sherman Law; consumer's complaint did not specify how, if at all, parent controlled or had any role in subsidiary's production and marketing process or vice versa, thus leaving only consumer's wholly generic and conclusory allegations of common scheme. Cal. Health & Safety Code § 109875 et seq.

Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.

Title: Twenty-Nine Palms Enterprises Corp. v. Bardos
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Neither the alter ego doctrine nor the piercing the corporate veil theory applied to allow owner of sole proprietorship contractor to claim use of contractor's license held by corporation for which owner was the responsible managing member; sole proprietorship was trying to pierce the corporate veil in order to circumvent the state's licensing statutes and admitted that owner created the corporate form for the purpose of self-dealing, and sole proprietorship was only trying to pierce the corporate veil in order to further the self-dealing. West's Ann.Cal.Bus. & Prof.Code § 7031.

Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, individual shareholder of corporation that owned bar could not be held personally liable for bar's alleged violation of New Jersey's Dram Shop Act and negligence, which allegedly resulted in death of patron when she fell off a dock while intoxicated, absent any allegations that shareholder used corporate form to defeat ends of justice, perpetrate a fraud, or otherwise evade the law or that the individual shareholder was at the bar or in contact with patron during the relevant time period. N.J.S.A. 2A:22A–4.

Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, credit counseling companies served as alter egos of companies' owners, and thus owners could be held personally liable for companies' violations of Credit Repair Organizations Act (CROA); owners had pervasive control over companies, which functioned without clear boundaries or separate corporate structures, owners liberally commingled companies' finances, using funds of one to pay bills of others, and owners, by immediately transferring new clients' accounts from one company to another, misled clients as to which entity was obligated to them. Headnote: An employee alleged sufficient detail to support a claim of corporate veil piercing against individual corporate employees in a False Claims Act retaliation claim. Court: United States District Court, N.D. Indiana, South Bend Division.

Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.

Headnote: Defendant, as high level corporate executive, convicted of conspiracy to commit bank fraud and related offenses, in connection with scheme to systematically defraud bank out of millions of dollars through corporation's revolving line of credit, was a person who obtained proceeds directly or indirectly, as result of criminal conduct, within meaning of criminal forfeiture statute, where defendant was alter ego of corporation. 18 U.S.C.A. § 982(a)(2).
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Forfeitures. Government provided adequate notice of its intent to seek criminal forfeiture in amount of $28,204,000.

Title: U.S. v. Peters
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Defendant, a high level corporate executive, who was convicted of conspiracy to commit bank fraud and related offenses, in connection with scheme to systematically defraud bank out of millions of dollars through corporation's revolving line of credit, dominated and controlled corporation such that it was his "alter ego" for purposes of piercing the corporate veil and imposing criminal forfeiture liability upon defendant; defendant and his wife purchased the corporation, defendant owned 13 percent, his wife owned 85 percent, defendant's sister-in-law owned one percent, and only one percent of the corporations was owned by non-family member, no one in the ownership group other than defendant controlled the corporations on a day-to-day basis, he transferred money in and out of corporate accounts, and defendant was directly involved in the renewal of revolving line of credit. 18 U.S.C.A. § 982(a)(2).
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Forfeitures. Government provided adequate notice of its intent to seek criminal forfeiture in amount of $28,204,000.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Long v. Aronov Realty Management, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Real estate brokerage firm's parent corporation had no principal-agent relationship with commercial real estate broker to trigger liability for alleged race discrimination against prospective lessee of space in shopping center; fact that broker handed prospective lessee a business card with parent corporation's name on it did not reflect the authority to bind parent corporation. 42 U.S.C.A. §§ 1981, 1982.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Discrimination. Summary judgment was precluded on discrimination claims relating to rental of shopping center space.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Telenor Mobile Communications AS v. Storm LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate shareholder's affiliates and parents were shareholder's alter egos, and thus were subject to civil contempt based on shareholder's failure to comply with provision of arbitration award resolving dispute with other shareholder that directed it to take certain actions with regard to its governance, where shareholder and affiliates existed entirely for purpose of holding shares for their parents, with no independent operations, shareholder exercised no meaningful discretion in its operations, but was instead wholly owned, dominated, and controlled by parents, there was intermingling of financial obligations and funds, with shareholder's assets used to secure loans to its corporate parents, and its legal bills paid by parent, parties made repeated attempts at conducting collusive litigation, and their efforts prevented other shareholder from taking part in corporate decision-making or from collecting dividends.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Contempt. Sanction of $100,000 per day, doubling every 30 days until shareholder complied with arbitration award, was appropriate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Charvat v. Farmers Ins. Columbus, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: Acts of insurance agent who was sole shareholder of insurance agency were in his capacity of a corporate officer for agency, and thus agent could not be personally liable for damages for alleged violations of Consumer Sales Practices Act (CSPA) resulting from telemarketing calls made by agency employees to call recipient's home, absent a showing that agent exercised control over agency so complete that agency had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, or that any such control was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act. R.C. § 1345.01 et seq.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Telecommunications. Insurance company could not be liable under Telephone Consumer Protection Act of 1991 (TCPA) for insurance sales telemarketing calls.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Olzens v. Lapuh
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Lake County.
Headnote: President and shareholder of moving corporation did not exercise control over corporation in such a way as to commit fraud or an illegal act against customers who used the corporation's services to move to a different state, and thus president and shareholder did not incur personal liability, on a theory of piercing the corporate veil, for losses suffered by customers when their personal belongings were damaged or lost during move.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Purported agent of non-existing moving corporation could be personally liable for losses from lost and damaged belongings.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: F.T.C. v. National Urological Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Dietary supplement companies operated as a "common enterprise" in advertising for various supplements, and thus each company could be held liable for deceptive act and practices of the other in action by Federal Trade Commission (FTC) alleging companies made deceptive representations to the public in their advertisements; all three companies were under the common control of the same president and officer, each company was at least influenced by a third officer, all three companies were run out of the same office space in an integrated fashion, and companies worked together to develop and advertise their products.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Advertising. FTC standards requiring scientific studies to support health or safety claims in advertisements were not void for vagueness.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Swayne v. Beebles Invests., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: Piercing of the corporate veil, to hold shareholder personally liable for violations of Ohio Mortgage Brokers Act by corporation licensed under the Act as mortgage broker, was warranted; shareholder exercised total and complete control over corporation, and shareholder used the corporate form and the privileges of the mortgage broker's license to engage in unconscionable transactions in which corporation made mortgage loan for which shareholder knew or should have known mortgagor would be unable to make balloon payment one year after loan origination, and in which corporation acquired title to the home, and leased it back to mortgagor, when she could not make the balloon payment. R.C. § 1322.01 et seq.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Mortgage loan for home repair was unconscionable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: U.S. ex rel. Purcell v. MWI Corp.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Payments made by United States Export-Import Bank, which were allegedly made based upon false claims, were conferred on defendant corporation and not its individual president, and thus government could not levy an unjust enrichment claim or payment by mistake claim against president, under District of Columbia law, without first successfully piercing the corporate veil, notwithstanding that president and his family were the sole shareholders of corporation.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - False Claims. Nigeria's alleged repayment of loans made to it by Import-Export Bank did not preclude damages in favor of government.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: In re Ma
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, corporate veil could be pierced, in order to hold shareholder liable on judgment entered against his wholly-owned corporation for its misconduct in connection with mortgage refinancing on which it acted as mortgage broker, where corporation was thinly capitalized at its inception, having only $500.00, and did not observe corporate formalities, where shareholder treated corporation liabilities as his own by using personal checks to pay corporate employees, where failure to pierce corporate veil would allow shareholder to evade liability for his unjust acts, such as in employing unlicensed loan officer, in materially underestimating closing costs, and in having borrower sign retention agreement in blank and altering its terms without borrower's consent, and where borrower's loss, in paying large sum of money for refinancing that did not accomplish her stated objective of lowering her monthly payments, was proximately caused by shareholder's control over corporation and its wrongdoing.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's misconduct as principal of mortgage broker was in nature of willful and malicious injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: U.S. v. Inn Foods, Inc.
Court: United States Court of International Trade.
Headnote: Shell corporation was alter ego or alias of importer, given that they were both owned and controlled by same people, had same phone number and operated from same building using same employees and officers in same roles, paid all invoices from importer's account, regardless of which was importer of record, had intermingled accounting ledgers, and combined their names on certain contracts, and therefore fact that corporation and importer were incorporated as separate entities did not shield importer from customs duties and penalties owed on actions that it took partly under corporation's name.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW - Customs and Tariffs. Importer's entries into United States by means of false and undervalued invoices was voluntary and intentional.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: S.E.C. v. Resource Development Intern., LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, corporate principal's use of corporate account in order to pay legal fees of friend who had organized Ponzi scheme, after this friend's assets were frozen, upon understanding that friend would immediately effect wire transfer from another account that he controlled in order to repay this fee advance, involved use of corporate form for illegal purpose, i.e., to assist friend in circumventing freeze order, and supported district court's decision to pierce corporate veil to hold corporate principal personally liable in connection with funds that were fraudulently wired to this corporate account to injury of transferor's creditors.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Judgment. Transfer by corporation operated as Ponzi scheme was actually and constructively fraudulent to creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Maganallez v. Hilltop Lending Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, borrowers' allegations against mortgage broker's licensed officer were sufficient to state claim on alter ego theory arising out of burdensome adjustable rate mortgage; borrowers alleged that broker was inadequately capitalized, failed to maintain corporate formalities, and was designed to limit officer's liability, that the individuality and separateness of officer and broker ceased to exist, and that adherence to the fiction of the broker's separate existence would sanction fraud and promote injustice.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Agents and Brokers. Borrowers stated RESPA claim against mortgage broker based on acceptance of yield spread premium.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Hegre v. Alberto-Culver USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Georgia, Augusta Division.
Headnote: In order to sue multiple entities under federal anti-discrimination laws, an employee must show that the entities function as a single employer or an integrated enterprise.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Store manager could not reasonably be regarded as disabled by bipolar disorder and hypertension.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Hegre v. Alberto-Culver USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Georgia, Augusta Division.
Headnote: In assessing whether corporate entities have interrelated operations, such that employee may sue multiple entities under federal anti-discrimination laws, courts consider whether the businesses have combined accounting records, bank accounts, lines of credit, payroll preparation, switchboard, telephone numbers, or offices.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Store manager could not reasonably be regarded as disabled by bipolar disorder and hypertension.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Richardson v. Bank of America, N.A.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Parent company of lender was not directly liable for lender's actions in regards to the selling of single-premium credit insurance in association with mortgage loans; the mere fact that there were overlapping officers between parent company and lender was insufficient to impose direct liability on parent and there was no evidence that the lender was operated as a mere instrumentality or alter ego of the parent company.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Sales and Marketing. Sale of single-premium credit insurance with loans greater than 15 years constituted an unlawful and deceptive trade practice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Butler v. Adoption Media, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Transferees of adoption website were not subject to alter ego liability under California law, with respect to action by same-sex domestic partners also brought against former operators of website; there was no evidence of bad faith in transfer of website, or that operators created transferees as separate entities to avoid operation of statute.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Adoption. California law governed anti-discrimination lawsuit brought by same-sex domestic partners seeking to adopt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Global Diagnostic Development, LLC v. Diagnostic Imaging of Atlanta
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Trial court that reviewed Department of Health's grant of a certificate of need to limited liability company (LLC) that bought the assets of corporation that was ordered to shut down its diagnostic imaging center for failing to obtain a certificate of need before relocating it could not disregard the corporate forms of LLC and corporation in concluding that the transaction attempted to accomplish indirectly what could not be accomplished directly, even though LLC and corporation were owned by same individual, where there was no evidence individual abused the corporate forms. West's Ga.Code Ann. § 31-6-1 et seq.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Department of Community Health's grant of certificate of need for diagnostic imaging facility was entitled to deference.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: In re Adler, Coleman Clearing Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Particular person was corporation's alter ego and control person under New York law, and as such was responsible for corporation's scheme of deception and market manipulation of stock of securities firm that served as introducing broker for securities clearing house, in violation of federal securities laws, which involved concerted naked short selling of that stock by corporation and cooperating traders that they did not own and thus could not deliver, where, among other things, such person admitted that he controlled that corporation and he otherwise invoked his privilege against self-incrimination when questioned about his direction of corporation's short trading in firm's stock. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 5; Securities Exchange Act of 1934, § 10(b), 15 U.S.C.A. § 78j(b); 17 C.F.R. § 240.10b-5.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Judgment. Control person could not challenge imposition of liability upon him for judgment entered by default against his alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Advanced Const. Corp. v. Pilecki
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: Homeowners could not pierce the corporate veil, in breach of contract, breach of warranty, negligence, violation of Home Construction Contract Act, violation of trade practices statutes, and abuse of process action against corporation home builder and its sole shareholder, absent evidence that corporation was undercapitalized, insolvent or bankrupt, or evidence that a verdict against corporation would be worth less than a verdict against shareholder. 10 M.R.S.A. §§ 1486-1490.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Evidence established that shareholder of home builder participated in wrongful acts and was personally liable to homeowners.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Widlar v. Young
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Lucas County.
Headnote: Customer of dating referral company failed to present evidence that company's principal exercised control over company in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against customer, and thus corporate veil could not be pierced to hold principal personally liable for company's acts; customer did not even allege that principal committed outright fraud, but rather sought to pierce the corporate veil on the basis of unfairness and inequity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Customer of dating referral company failed to present evidence that principal used his control of company to commit fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Menorah Campus Independent Sr. Apartments, Inc. v. Novello
Court: Supreme Court, Erie County, New York.
Headnote: In determining whether corporation's subsidiary that leased units in residential apartment buildings to tenants 65 or older was an adult care facility (ACF) subject to licensing under the Social Services Law, Department of Health did not have authority to pierce corporate veil between the subsidiary, its parent corporation, and another subsidiary that provided home care services. McKinney's Social Services Law § 2(21); 18 NYCRR 488.7(c)(1), (c)(2)(I)(2), (d, e).
Document Preview: HEALTH - Residential Facilities. Corporation that offered hotel-type amenities to senior residents was not an adult care facility subject to licensing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Upperman v. Grange Indemn. Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Common Pleas of Ohio, Franklin County.
Headnote: Insureds stated claim to pierce the corporate veil and hold parent corporation liable for automobile insurers' alleged fraud and violation of statutory requirement to file rate increase with Department of Insurance; vice president's letter showing awareness of decision not to refund the illegally charged premiums was unclear as to his position with regard to parent or subsidiaries. R.C. § 3937.03(A, H).
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Premiums. Insureds had implied private right of action against automobile insurers for charging unfiled rates.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: In re Parmalat Securities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Class of shareholders in Italian company, which was audited by Italian affiliate of global accounting firm prior to company's collapse upon the discovery of a massive fraud that reportedly involved the understatement of its debt and the overstatement of its net assets, did not adequately alleged an alter ego relationship under New York law between global firm and its United States affiliate such that United States affiliate could be vicariously liable for the alleged securities fraud committed by Italian affiliate; without pleading any facts that would tend to show that United States affiliate used the close relationship to dominate global firm, an alter ego relationship could not be inferred from the close relationship and overlap in executives.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Global accounting firm was subject to liability for alleged securities fraud committed by Italian member firm.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: State v. Weinschenk
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil was warranted in state's action against builder and builder's construction corporation under state Unfair Trade Practices Act (UTPA), and thus builder could be held personal liable for corporation's actions; builder had direct, personal dealings with each of original purchasers and personally misrepresented quality of houses, corporation was thinly capitalized and insolvent at time of trial, builder, as the only officer and director, had pervasive control over corporation, and holding only bankrupt corporation liable would have led to unjust and inequitable result for injured homeowners. 5 M.R.S.A. § 205-A, et seq.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Protection. Indirect purchasers of defective houses were not entitled to restitution in state's action under Unfair Trade Practices Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Rayner v. Reeves Custom Builders, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Administrative code chapter governing unfair trade practices in area of home improvement allows for piercing of corporate veil to impose liability on individual wrongdoers when individual, rather than entity, is responsible for devising unfair method of selling home improvements. W.S.A. 100.20(2); Wis.Admin. Code § 110.01(5).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Protection. Regulations governing unfair trade practices in area of home improvement allow for piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Bowoto v. Chevron Texaco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Oil corporation and its subsidiary were not alter egos of a company owned by the subsidiary, so as to support imposition of liability, on an alter ego theory, regarding human rights abuse claims asserted by Nigerian citizens; there was no evidence that incorporation was undertaken in bad faith or that observing the corporate form would achieve an inequitable result, despite any inability of the Nigerians to recover for their losses against the company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Whether to pierce corporate veil on ratification theory was triable fact issue.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Graves v. Tubb
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Mississippi, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Mississippi law, employee of credit reporting agency's corporate subscriber could not be considered an alter ego of the subscriber, so as to impose alter ego liability on subscriber for employee's alleged Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) violations, based on employee's position as employee relations supervisor; there was no indication that employee stood in employer's shoes or that he was employed to bring about business relations between employer and third parties. Consumer Credit Protection Act, § 603(b), as amended, 15 U.S.C.A. § 1681a(b).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Credit. Employer was not liable for employee's Fair Credit Reporting Act violation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Electrical Workers Pension Trust Fund of Local Union |58, IBEW v. Gary's Elec. Service Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: If a corporate officer avoids a court's order to the corporation by failing to take action or attempt compliance, the officer, no less than the corporation itself, is guilty of disobedience, and may be punished for contempt, notwithstanding the officer's nonparty status; moreover, because a civil contempt ruling either attempts to coerce compliance or compensate the complainant for losses, it is fully appropriate to impose judicial sanctions on the nonparty corporate officer.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Contempt. Corporate officer could be held in contempt for disobeying order directed to corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Orenbuch v. North Shore Health Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, mere fact that hospital utilized the services of affiliated support services organization and its subdivision to collect hospital debts was insufficient to support finding of virtual abandonment of separateness or the kind of economic control required to consider the entities as one or to pierce the corporate veil, for purposes of consumer's action based on affiliate's alleged violations of Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA). Consumer Credit Protection Act, §§ 807(14), 809, as amended, 15 U.S.C.A. §§ 1692e(14), 1692g.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Debt collector's nondisclosure of relationship with affiliated organizations did not violate FDCPA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: S.E.C. v. Hickey
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under California law, court's order for asset freeze against real estate brokerage wholly owned by contemnor's mother, as part of equitable enforcement of contempt order arising from failure to pay disgorgement in securities fraud enforcement action, did not require finding of alter ego relationship permitting piercing of brokerage; freeze did not constitute imposition of liability on brokerage for contemnor's debt.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Court could freeze assets of nonparty controlled by SEC fraud defendant, to enforce disgorgement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Jet, Inc. v. Shell Oil Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Franchisee stated Petroleum Marketing Practices Act (PMPA) claim against corporate affiliates under alter ego theory, on allegations that affiliates commingled corporate revenues and funds, they used corporate revenues and funds to pay expenses and debts of other affiliates, they failed to keep separate or adequate corporate records or hold regular meetings, and they used multiple corporate entities to perpetuate a fraud against franchisee and general public, and adherence to fiction of corporate separateness would have sanctioned fraud or promoted injustice. Petroleum Marketing Practices Act, § 101 et seq., 15 U.S.C.A. § 2801 et seq.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Petroleum Marketing Practices Act. PMPA did not permit cause of action, or implied cause of action, for constructive termination.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Industrias Magromer Cueros y Pieles S.A. v. Louisiana Bayou Furs Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Misrepresentation of material facts by chairman of Louisiana fur company, during contract negotiations between fur company and Argentinian company, did not warrant piercing the corporate veil such that chairman would be personally liable for fur company's violation of the Louisiana Unfair Trade Practices Act (LUTPA); although chairman misrepresented material facts during contract negotiations, he did not do so with the intention either to obtain an unjust advantage over Argentinian company or to cause a loss or inconvenience to Argentinian company. LSA–R.S. 51:1401 et seq.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Sales. Evidence supported jury's finding that fur company and its chairman acted in bad faith in failing to perform under contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: McClellan v. Northridge Park Townhome Owners Ass'n, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: When a corporation is used by an individual or individuals, or by another corporation, to perpetrate a fraud, circumvent a statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose, a court may disregard the corporate entity and treat the acts as if they were done by the individuals themselves or by the controlling corporation; the court will disregard the fiction of corporate entity.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Condominiums. Evidence supported finding that homeowners association was mere continuation of predecessor association.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1061 Evasion or violation of law or orders in general >
Title: Lawlor v. District of Columbia
Court: District of Columbia Court of Appeals.
Headnote: Officer of private corporation that was awarded contract to manage nursing home owned by the District of Columbia was personally liable, as a corporate shareholder, to employees on their claim under the Wage Payment Law; corporate veil was pierced by officer's conduct in transferring assets to another corporation that he controlled in order to shield them from taxing authorities, and in misleading employees into believing that their obligations to the government and creditors were being satisfied, was part of a deceptive scheme that proximately led to the collapse of the corporations and the failure to pay wages. Headnote: Where charter bus company provided its school bus subsidiary with management service without receiving in return an aliquot share of cost, furnished it with capital funds on only relatively small portion of which it received return, and repaired on its premises and with its personnel school buses without reward other than recapture of its out-of-pocket expenses, public utility administrator's determination, in proceeding to determine proper fare structure, that identity of subsidiary had been merged with that of parent was not unreasonable. Pub.Laws 1959, c. 144, § 7.
Document Preview: Separate appeals by bus company and private citizen from an order of the Public Utility Administrator which permitted bus company to abandon its operations on certain routes but refused company's request to increase its fare structure. The Supreme Court, Joslin, J., held that a remand was necessary to afford administrator an opportunity to file an additional or supplementary decision in which he would disclose the evidentiary facts which caused him to disallow company's estimate of charitable contributions and projected general and administrative expenses as part of operating revenues' and that the administrator went beyond his jurisdiction when he permitted bus company to completely abandon its operations along certain routes. Remanded with directions.

Title: State of S.D. v. National Bank of S.D., Sioux Falls
Court: United States Court of Appeals Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Record failed to establish that District Court erred in determining that corporate veil of national bank, which effected merger with state banks, should not be pierced to enable state attacking such merger to show that transaction should be treated as acquisition by bank holding company, which owned over ninety per cent of stock of national bank, rather than by national bank itself. Title: Little v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Where incorporators of corporation were three attorneys in office of counsel employed by defendant charged with violating Securities Act, stock record book revealed one certificate issued in name of defendant but "never actually executed" by any officer of corporation, and defendant was president and his wife was secretary of corporation, doctrine of corporate alter ego applied, and legal fiction of corporation was required to be ignored to prevent fraud and accomplish justice. Securities Act of 1933, § 17(a), 15 U.S.C.A. § 77q(a).
Document Preview: Defendant was convicted of violating the Securities Act, and from a judgment of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri, Roy W. Harper, J., the defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Ridge, Circuit Judge, held, inter alia, that the clearance of duped investors' checks through bank in Tennessee and federal reserve bank in Missouri was a direct or indirect use of the mails' by defendant who was permitted to withdraw funds from bank upon receipt of the checks in execution of his scheme to defraud in violation of Securities Act, as against contention that he was free from fraud because he was permitted to withdraw funds before checks were cleared through the federal reserve bank. Affirmed.

Title: Rosenhouse v. Kimbrig
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Second District.
Headnote: Where corporate borrower had been in existence for three years and had owned mortgaged property for six months prior to time that endorser of corporation's note sought to obtain loan on such property, and all parties to loan conceived of it as being made to corporation, the rule that corporate shell to cloak a loan to individual borrower will not be allowed to defeat usury laws was inapplicable notwithstanding fact that four days after loan was closed mortgaged premises were conveyed by corporation to endorser individually. F.S.A. §§ 687.02, 687.03.
Document Preview: Mortgage foreclosure suit. From a summary final decree of the Circuit Court, Brevard County, Vassar B. Carlton, J., the defendants appealed and plaintiff moved for attorney's fees. The District Court of Appeal, Allen, Acting C. J., held, inter alia, that where corporate borrower had been in existence for three years and had owned mortgaged property for six months prior to time that endorser of corporation's note sought to obtain loan on such property, and all parties to loan conceived of it as being made to corporation, the rule that corporate shell to cloak a loan to individual borrower will not be allowed to defeat the usury laws was inapplicable notwithstanding fact that four days after loan was closed, mortgaged premises were conveyed by corporation to endorser individually. Decree affirmed, and petition for attorney's fees denied.

Title: Wheeler v. Superior Mortg. Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: That two corporations were used to make usurious loans, with one corporation taking brokerage fee or commission and other nominally and informally making loan, indicated bad faith, and plea of separate entities could not be accepted in usury case. West's Ann.Civ.Code, § 1916-1 et seq.; West's Ann.Const. art. 20, § 22.
Document Preview: Action to recover treble interest payments made on two usurious loan transactions. From a judgment of the Superior Court, Los Angeles County, David Coleman, J., for the plaintiff, the defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Balthis, J., held that the evidence sustained the findings, and that the lender's bidding in the property securing the loans at the trustee's sale for an amount including the interest claimed was the equivalent of payment by the borrower and justified application of the treble damage provision of the Usury Act. Affirmed.

Title: Stark v. Flemming
Court: United States Court of Appeals Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Where woman placed her assets, a farm and a duplex house, in newly organized corporation, and began drawing $400 per month as salary, and, although corporation undoubtedly was set up to qualify her in a short time for social security payments, there was proper adherence to normal corporate routines, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare was required to respect corporate arrangement, but was entitled to make objective reappraisal of salary to determine what would have been a reasonable salary for services performed.
Document Preview: Action for review of ruling of Secretary of Department of Health, Education and Welfare that plaintiff was not entitled to old-age benefits. The United States District Court for the Northern District of California, Southern Division, William T. Sweigert, J., 181 F.Supp. 539, entered judgment adverse to plaintiff, and she appealed. The Court of Appeals held that where plaintiff placed her assets, a farm and a duplex house, in newly organized corporation, and began drawing $400 per month as salary, and, although corporation undoubtedly was set up to qualify her in a short time for social security payments, there was proper adherence to normal corporate routines, Secretary was required to respect corporate arrangement, but was entitled to make objective reappraisal of salary to determine what would have been a reasonable salary for services performed. Judgment vacated and case remanded with directions.

Title: Von Hennig v. Rogers
Court: United States District Court District of Columbia.
Headnote: Even if an Italian business organization could be regarded as a corporation, rather than a partnership, in view of fact it was a closely held family corporation in which a plaintiff, who sought return of property seized by the alien property custodian, had a half interest, and the activities of such organization were continuously supervised by him, under such circumstances, equity would pierce the veil of the corporate entity, and the court would conclude that such plaintiff, through such business organization, was carrying on business in Italy during the crucial years. Trading with the Enemy Act, § 2(a), 50 U.S.C.A.Appendix, § 2(a).
Document Preview: Action under the Trading with the Enemy Act to secure return of certain property seized by the alien property custodian during World War II. The original plaintiff died during the pendency of the action and his auxiliary executor was substituted as party plaintiff. The District Court, Holtzoff, J., held that evidence established that original plaintiff, during the crucial war years, was doing business in enemy territory, namely, Italy, and that he was therefore not a qualified claimant under the Trading with the Enemy Act. Judgment for defendant in accordance with opinion.

Title: Lesser v. Strubbe
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey Chancery Division.
Headnote: The mere use of corporate form cannot be permitted to obscure true facts and sanction exaction of usury with impunity and in disregard of public policy against it. N.J.S.A. 31:1-6; General Business Law N.Y. § 374.
Document Preview: Two mortgage foreclosure actions and mortgages suit to have guaranty agreements and mortgage declared void as to her were consolidated for trial. The Chancery Division, Scherer, J.S.C., held that the loan represented by corporation's note secured by mortgages had been a loan to individual defendant rather than a loan to corporation and that defense of usury was thus available to defendants, and held that since constructive notice of fraud practiced upon defendant wife by her husband had been brought home to plaintiff by circumstances, doctrine of unclean hands should be applied. Judgment accordingly.

Title: Gilbert v. Doris R. Corp.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Use of corporate shell to cloak a loan, which is actually being made to an individual borrower, will not be allowed to defeat usury laws which provide that interest charged individuals should not exceed 10 percent and that interest charged corporations should not exceed 15 per cent. F.S.A. §§ 687.02 to 687.04.
Document Preview: Suit in equity was brought for a declaratory decree to define the rights of the parties as result of a mortgage loan, for which usurious interest was allegedly charged, and the defendants counterclaimed for foreclosure. The Circuit Court, for Dade County, Vincent C. Giblin, J., entered a judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, and the defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Carroll, Chas., C. J., held that use of a corporate shell to cloak a loan, which is actually being made to an individual borrower, will not be allowed to defeat the usury laws of the state, and that evidence sustained finding of Chancellor that corporation was used as a borrower, when loan was actually being made to individuals, in order to avoid usury laws, and that therefore the loan was usurious. Decree affirmed.

Title: Pfaffenberger v. Pavilion Restaurant Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: In action for unlawful sale of intoxicating liquors to plaintiff's minor son, where declaration alleged that liquor license under which unlawful sale was made had been issued in name of a third corporation and that title to realty on which business was conducted was held in the name of one corporation, if proofs established such confusion of affairs of three corporations and such domination and manipulation of business of licensed corporation by other two through common stock holders and officers and a combination of the operation of the three corporations, corporate entities could be disregarded.
Document Preview: Action for damages resulting from alleged unlawful sale of intoxicating liquors to the minor son of plaintiff. Judgment for defendants in the Circuit Court of Allegan County, Raymond L. Smith, J., and the plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Dethmers, C. J., held that pleadings were sufficient to charge all defendants with wrongful acts. Reversed.

Title: People v. Dalsis
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: The trial court could not pierce the corporate veil and install defendant, who was principal and sole stockholder of corporation as "trustee" under trust receipts agreement between corporation and bank for financing of automobiles, where defendant was accused, as trustee, in first degree grand larceny charge of withholding money and automobiles belonging to bank. Personal Property Law, §§ 51, subd. 14, 58-e, subd. 2; Penal Law, § 1302.
Document Preview: Prosecution for first degree grand larceny wherein defendant, who was president of corporation which had executed statement of trust receipt with bank for financing of automobiles, was accused as trustee of withholding and appropriating to his own use money and automobiles belonging to bank. Defendant's motion to dismiss indictment was denied and judgment of conviction was entered upon jury verdict in County Court, Cattaraugus County, Philip J. Weiss, J., and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Barstow, J., held that there was insufficient evidence before grand jury to warrant returning the indictment. Reversed and indictment dismissed.

Title: Baim & Blank v. Philco Corp
Court: United States District Court E.D. New York.
Headnote: Mere fact that a corporate distributor was a wholly owned subsidiary of a corporate manufacturer, and that officers of distributor with one exception were also officers of manufacturer, did not establish that distributor was merely the alter ego of manufacturer for purposes of establishing that the two corporations should be regarded as a single entity constituting a "common seller" discriminating between their customers, within meaning of Robinson-Patman Act. Clayton Act, § 2(a, d, e) as amended by Robinson-Patman Price Discrimination Act, 15 U.S.C.A. § 13(a, d, e).
Document Preview: Action against corporate manufacturer and its wholly owned distributor for damages for price discriminations. The District Court, Galston, J., held that where manufacturer controlled prices of its products sold directly to retail dealers, but prices fixed by its distributor were not established by parent manufacturer but by distributor itself, sales by distributor to plaintiff both before and after date manufacturer ceased direct sales to a certain buyer, were not such sales that manufacturer and distributor could be regarded as a single entity to the end they constituted a common seller discriminating in price between their customers, within meaning of Robinson-Patman Act. Motion granted.

Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: In prosecution of president of bankrupt corporation for grand theft, on information charging that he had taken property of corporation, evidence would sustain finding that corporation was not defendant's alter ego, notwithstanding his contention that he owned all of corporation's stock.

Headnote: In proceeding for writ of mandate to compel Board of Equalization to annul its order revoking general on-sale license to sell alcoholic beverages at saloon and restaurant, wherein corporation contended its license could not be revoked for violations after December 27, 1951, in view of fact corporation was merely agent for shareholders who purchased all corporation stock on that date, and corporation requested court to pierce corporate veil and apply doctrine of alter ego, evidence was insufficient to warrant Board to disregard corporate entity. Court: United States Court of Appeals Second Circuit.
Headnote: Existence of separate corporate entity should not be permitted to frustrate a federal regulatory statute. Commodity Exchange Act, § 1 et seq., 7 U.S.C.A. § 1 et seq.
Document Preview: Proceeding for review of decision and order of Secretary of Agriculture rendered pursuant to Commodity Exchange Act and regulations promulgated thereunder. Court: Supreme Court of New Jersey.
Headnote: Use of corporate shell to cloak loan which was actually made to individual borrower will in nowise be permitted to defeat the usury laws of State. R.S. 31:1-6, N.J.S.A.

Headnote: In proceeding to revoke a liquor license for violation by the licensee of minimum resale price lists, the licensee's corporate shell did not render it immune to revocation of its license because of conduct of person who with his wife owned 48 of the 50 shares of corporate stock. Court: United States Court of Appeals Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: To establish substantial identity between parent corporation and subsidiary for purposes of the Trade Commission Act, Clayton Act, and the Robinson-Patman Price Discrimination Act, there must be evidence of such complete control of the subsidiary by the parent as to render subsidiary mere tool of parent and to compel conclusion that corporate identity of subsidiary is mere fiction. Title: Eastman Kodak Co. v. Schwartz
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Special Term, Part IX.
Headnote: That manufacturing corporation owned all of the stock of retail corporations did not make retail corporations agents of the plaintiff nor retail corporations' acts those of the manufacturing corporation, for purpose of determining, for fair trade law purposes, whether manufacturer was also a retailer. Document Preview: Action to enforce fair trade agreements. Judgment in accordance with opinion.

Title: Alkow v. State Bar of Cal.
Court: Supreme Court of California, in Bank.
Headnote: In proceedings for review of board of governors' recommendation of three years' suspension from practice of law, based, in part, upon conduct of attorney in connection with corporation doing business as collection agency, question would be whether attorney's conduct in connection with collection agency complied with prescribed standards of conduct for members of legal profession, and it would be of no significance whether or not there had been evidence showing such a unity of interest and ownership as would justify disregard of separate corporate entity of collection agency.

Title: State v. Stemen
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second District, Darke County.
Headnote: Where corporation was, in effect, alter ego of defendant charged with drawing checks with intent to defraud, when checks were issued by employee of corporation acting within scope of her authority and by direction and permission of defendant and not by defendant personally, corporate fiction could not shield defendant from criminal responsibility, but corporate entity might be disregarded. Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Where president and treasurer of corporation engaged in furnishing movie information to prospective theather patrons, were instrumental in creating corporation engaged in supplying racing information to bookmakers by use of telephone equipment furnished movie information corporation, such corporation through its officers was aware of services rendered to bookmakers by means of equipment furnished to it by telephone company, even if conducted by separate and independent corporation, and was not entitled to order compelling restoration of telephone service. Title: Mansfield Journal Co. (FM) v. Federal Communications Commission
Court: United States Court of Appeals District of Columbia Circuit
Headnote: Where two newspapers owned by same family applied for radio broadcasting licenses in nearby towns, Federal Communications Commission was entitled to look beyond corporate name, and notice character of individual owner and where Commission's considered opinion as to probable conduct was based on sufficient evidence, Court of Appeals would not disturb it. Communications Act of 1934, §§ 308, 311, 47 U.S.C.A. §§ 308, 311.
Document Preview: Proceedings in the matters of the applications of Mansfield Journal Company (AM) and (FM).  The Lorain Journal Company, and Laurence W. Harry, trading as Fostoria Broadcasting Company, for radio broadcasting licenses. The Federal Communications commission denied applications of Mansfield Journal Company and The Lorain Journal Company, ordered application of the Fostoria Broadcasting Company to be placed in the pending file, and the Mansfield Journal Company and the Lorain Journal Company appealed. The Court of Appeals, Washington, Circuit Judge, held that evidence was sufficient to justify denial of broadcasting licenses to applicants on the ground of public convenience, interest and necessity where there was a danger of monopoly in mass communication of news and advertising contrary to public interest. Decisions affirmed.

Title: Bigelow v. RKO Radio Pictures
Court: United States Court of Appeals Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Where case was tried with only one defendant from corporate group with interlocking officers and directors and common control and there were repeated admissions as well as testimony by witnesses holding responsible positions in such group that defendant owned and operated certain theater in the territory involved and defendant was enjoined from delaying exhibition by permitting a run of picture longer than two weeks in a theater owned or operated by defendant, etc., defendant could not evade punishment for disobeying the injunction by proof that not the defendant but another wholly owned subsidiary operated such theater.

Affirmed.

Court: District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division
Headnote: A corporation has an existence separate and apart from those of the persons constituting its officers and agents and corporation may be guilty of violations of law separate and apart from the guilt or innocence of its officers.

Title: Schenley Distillers Corp. v. U.S.
Court: Supreme Court of the United States
Headnote: One who has created a corporate arrangement, chosen as a means of carrying out his business purposes, does not have the choice of disregarding the corporate entity in order to avoid obligations which the Interstate Commerce Act lays on it for the protection of the public. Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: The setting of corporation's mill on fire to collect insurance would not be charged to corporation to prejudice of innocent stockholders, if act was done by an officer not authorized by stockholders or by act of one but not the sole stockholder; but, if one setting the fire is practically the sole stockholder, the corporate entity will be disregarded and his fraud be held as that of corporation.

From summary judgment, the plaintiffs appeal. Reversed.

Title: State Bd. of Funeral Directors and Embalmers v. Cooksey
Court: Supreme Court of Florida, en Banc.
Headnote: Although a corporation, under statute, could engage in the business of funeral directing, and one whose license as funeral director had been revoked was not prohibited from owning stock in such corporation, he could not use such corporation as a means to evade an order restraining him from engaging in the business of funeral directing either directly or indirectly, and by so doing he was guilty of contempt. F.S.A. §§ 470.01 et seq., 470.10.

Cooksey, seeking to have respondent punished for contempt for alleged violation of an order prohibiting respondent from engaging in the business of funeral directing. From the decree, the State Board of Funeral Directors and Embalmers appeals. Reversed. BUFORD, TERRELL, and BROWN, JJ., dissenting.

Title: State v. Swift & Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Courts look beyond the corporate form to purpose of corporation and officers identified with that purpose to determine whether a single or integrated public utility business is being operated by two or more affiliated corporations, particularly with respect to exercise of regulatory powers by public administrative bodies, since to permit such public utilities to operate through other separate legal entities created and owned by them would enable them to defeat the jurisdiction of such administrative bodies over such integrated or affiliated corporate businesses.

From a judgment that it take nothing by its suit against either defendant, plaitiff appeals. Judgment affirmed.

Title: Ohio Tank Car Co. v. Keith Ry. Equipment Co.
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Where one corporation marketed petroleum products and another operated a fleet of tank cars, both corporations being owned in same proportions and by same stockholders and having with minor differences, same officers and directors, the two corporations would be considered as same corporation and their respective stockholders considered the same for purpose of applying statute prohibiting all rebates, concessions, or discriminations in respect to transportation of property in interstate commerce by common carrier. Elkins Act § 1(1), 49 U.S.C.A. § 41(1).

From a judgment dismissing the complaint and ordering payment of the counterclaim, the plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Title: Nichols & Co. v. Secretary of Agriculture
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Secretary of Agriculture, in suspending registration of partnership as commission merchant under Commodity Exchange Act for alleged violations of the Act, was not justified in attributing wrongs of corporation, for which partnership was allegedly mere agent, to the partnership, although there was an identity of individuals who controlled the corporation and partnership, and it appeared that partnership and corporation were on same floor in building, that corporation had granted loans to partnership, and that partnership handled corporation's futures business, where it appeared that major portion of partnership's business was done with others than the corporation, and that partnership carried on a substantial business in its own right as a separate, distinct entity. Commodity Exchange Act § 1 et seq., 7 U.S.C.A. § 1 et seq.

Title: Nichols & Co. v. Secretary of Agriculture
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Where complaint charged corporation which was controlled by same individuals who also controlled a partnership registered as a commission agent under Commodities Exchange Act with violation of section of the Act prohibiting a member of a contract market from acting on other side of customers' trades without their consent, but did not charge the partnership with such violation, upon establishment of separate entities of the corporation and the partnership, punishment of partnership on erroneous theory that partnership was instrumentality of the corporation could not be sustained. Title: State ex rel. Monarch Fire Ins. Co. v. Holmes

Headnote: Where State Insurance Commissioner's orders directing insurance companies to show cause why their licenses should not be revoked merely alleged that companies were subsidiaries of a parent corporation which had engaged in certain practices within the state and that such practices should be charged to companies, and there was no showing that companies were the alter ego of parent or a business conduit of parent, or that corporate cloak of companies was or would be used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience or to justify wrong, the orders did not justify disregarding corporate entities and did not allege sufficient grounds for revocation of licenses.
